title: 106_hr4776
content: The "Fuel Excise Tax Relief Act" suspends fuel taxes through March 31, 2001. During the suspension period, all fuel taxes will be reduced to zero, including taxes on diesel fuel, special motor fuels, certain alcohol fuels, fuel used in commercial transportation on inland waterways, gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, and aviation fuel. During the suspension period, fuel taxes will be reduced to zero, including taxes on various types of fuel such as diesel, gasoline, kerosene, and aviation fuel. The suspension period is defined as the period from the enactment of the Act until March 31, 2001. The 1993 increases in certain motor fuel taxes are repealed. The 1993 increases in certain motor fuel taxes are repealed. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding diesel fuel used in trains, fuel used on inland waterways, gasoline used in trains, and aviation gasoline. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change the tax rates for aviation fuel and diesel fuel used in trains. Additionally, technical amendments are made to certain sections regarding diesel fuel taxes. The tax rates for aviation fuel and diesel fuel used in trains are amended in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Technical amendments are made to certain sections regarding diesel fuel taxes, including exemptions for certain sales and uses. The tax rates for aviation fuel and diesel fuel used in trains are amended in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 4041(a)(1) is modified to subsections (d)(3) and (a)(1) of section 4041. Amendments are made to sections 4083(a), 4091(b)(3), and 4091(c) regarding diesel fuel taxes. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including changes to aviation fuel and diesel fuel tax rates. Subsection (c) of section 4091 is amended by redesignating paragraphs, and subsection (b) of section 4092 is modified to include definitions for "commercial aviation." Subparagraph (B) of section 6421(f)(2) is also revised. Amendments are made to sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding gasoline and diesel fuel taxes for trains. Paragraphs in sections 6421(f) and 6427(l) are amended to exclude certain taxes on fuel used in trains. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exclude certain fuel taxes for trains, with changes to sections 6421(f) and 6427(l) taking effect on April 1, 2001. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. If a tax has been imposed on liquid before the tax suspension date and the liquid is held by a dealer for sale, the taxpayer can claim a credit or refund for the excess tax paid. Claims must be filed within 6 months of the tax suspension date. No credit or refund allowed for liquid in retail stocks held for retail sale. Definitions for "dealer" and "held by a dealer" provided in this section. The terms "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are defined in section 6412 of the Code, with "dealer" including a producer. The "tax suspension date" is the start of the suspension period under section 2(b). Rules similar to section 6412 of the Code apply to this section. SEC. 5. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be due under the Internal Revenue Code if the taxable event occurred on that date. Liability and Payment: The person holding the liquid is liable for the tax, to be paid as prescribed by the Secretary within 6 months of the floor stocks tax date. The floor stocks tax date is April 1, 2001. Taxable liquid is defined as any liquid subject to a tax on that date. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. An exception is made for taxable liquid held for exempt uses. No tax is imposed on liquid held in a vehicle tank or up to 2,000 gallons of liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, as long as the required information is submitted to the Secretary. Fuel held by a person exempt from tax under certain conditions is not considered. Controlled groups are treated as one person, with specific criteria outlined in the tax code. Under regulations prescribed by the Secretary, similar principles apply to a group of persons under common control where one or more are not corporations. All provisions of law applicable to taxes imposed by chapter 31 or 32 apply to floor stock taxes imposed under this section. SEC. 6. MAINTENANCE OF TRUST FUND DEPOSITS. An amount equal to the reduction in revenues to the Treasury by reason of a reduction in any rate under this Act shall be treated as taxes received in the Treasury under such rate. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Energy, must submit a study to Congress on fuel price changes and the impact of the Clean Air Act on fuel prices. The Comptroller General will also study tax reductions to determine if consumers benefit. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress within 60 days of the enactment of the Act, detailing the results of the study on tax reductions and their impact on consumers.
